Navigation
Name Recipes/Common/Crawl
Synopsis Crawl a file system and collect files with given extension
Description A Web Crawler is a program that browses web pages in a systematic manner. Here we present a crawler for files in a file system, although it can easily be extended to browse the web as well.
Examples 
module demo::common::Crawl

import IO;
import String;

public list[loc] crawl(loc dir, str suffix){
  res = [];
  for(str entry <- listEntries(dir)){
      loc sub = dir + entry;   
      if(isDirectory(sub)) {
          res += crawl(sub, suffix);
      } else {
	      if(endsWith(entry, suffix)) { 
	         res += [sub]; 
	      }
      }
  };
  return res;
}

public list[loc] crawl2(loc dir, str suffix){
  return 
	  for(str entry <- listEntries(dir)){
	      loc sub = dir + entry;  
	      if(isDirectory(sub)) {
	          append crawl(sub, suffix);  
	      } else {
		      if(endsWith(entry, suffix)) { 
		         append [sub];           
		      }
	      }
	  };
}

public list[loc] crawl3(loc dir, str suffix) =
  isDirectory(dir) ? [crawl(e,ext) | e <- dir.ls] : (dir.extension == ext ? [dir] : []);
The crawl function takes two arguments:
  • The directory dir where the crawl should start.
  • The suffix of the files we are looking for.
The crawler simply lists all entries in the current directory using Rascal:listEntries and adds all files that end we the given suffix to the result. If an entry is itself a directory, it is crawled by a recursive call to crawl. At we use concatenation on a location and a string; it automatically adds a / separator, see Rascal:Location for details.

We also show shorter versions crawl2 and crawl3 that we further discuss below.

Let's now crawl the demo files used in this course: 
rascal>import demo::common::Crawl;
ok
rascal>files = crawl(|std://library/demo|, ".rsc");
list[loc]: [|std://library/demo/basic/Ackermann.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/Bottles.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/Bubble.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/BubbleTest.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/Factorial.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/FactorialTest.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/FizzBuzz.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/Hello.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/Quine.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/Squares.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/Calls.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/ColoredTrees.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/ColoredTreesTest.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/CountConstructors.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/Crawl.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/Cycles.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/Derivative.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/Lift.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/LiftTest.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/StringTemplate.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/StringTemplateTest.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/Trans.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/WordCount/CountInLine1.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/WordCount/CountInLine2.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/WordCount/CountInLine3.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/WordCount/Jabberwocky.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/WordCount/WordCount.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/WordReplacement.rsc|,|std://library/demo/common/WordReplacementTest.rsc|,|std://library/demo/Dominators.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Abstract/Eval.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Abstract/Syntax.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Abstract/Test.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Combined/Automatic/Eval.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Combined/Automatic/Load.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Combined/Automatic/Parse.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Combined/Automatic/Syntax.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Combined/Manual/Eval.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Combined/Manual/Load.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Combined/Manual/Parse.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Concrete/NoLayout/Eval.rsc|,|std://library/demo/lang/Exp/Concrete/NoLayout/Syntax.rsc|,|std://library This list can be the starting point for further investigation, for instance, to compute the number of files; 
rascal>import List;
ok
rascal>size(files);
int: 120
or to compute the total number of lines in these files: 
rascal>import IO;
ok
rascal>(0 | it + size(readFileLines(f)) | loc f <- files);
int: 4617
This above example uses a Rascal:Reducer expression.

Finally, we can look for the largest files. First import some libraries we will need. 
rascal>import Relation;
ok
rascal>import Set;
ok
Create a relation aux of <location, length> pairs: 
rascal>aux = {<f, size(readFileLines(f))> | loc f <- files};

Now determine the maximum length (using Rascal:size), by taking the maximum of the Rascal:range of aux: 
rascal>m = max(range(aux));
int: 283
and now Rascal:invert aux and use Rascal:Subscription to find the tuples with the maximum value as first element. 
rascal>invert(aux)[m];
set[loc]: {|std://library/demo/vis/Logo.rsc|}
In the listing given above, there are two alternative versions of crawl:
  • crawl2 uses Rascal:Append (at and ) to avoid introducing a local variable res as done in crawl.
  • crawl3 is the shortest version that depends on a list comprehension and on the ls field of locations.
Let's try them: 
rascal>import demo::common::Crawl;
ok
rascal>files2 = crawl(|std://library/demo|, ".rsc");
list[loc]:
